text: Any idea where can I find ToQ.jl <https://www.researchgate.net/publication/311314210_ToQjl_A_high-level_programming_language_for_D-Wave_machines_based_on_Julia|https://www.researchgate.net/publication/311314210_ToQjl_A_high-level_programming_language_for_D-Wave_machines_based_on_Julia>?

elements.text: Any idea where can I find ToQ.jl

text:
I think it's now called ThreeQ.jl
<https://github.com/omalled/ThreeQ.jl>
You can check the commit history.

elements.text: I think it's now called ThreeQ.jl
You can check the commit history.

text:
Thanks！Just checked that out！
I think its been abandoned...
I think it'd make more sense building one from scratch in Julia, instead of porting one of the existing ones. Then make the new one compatible with the existing ones. (Kind of like how Yao did it:slightly_smiling_face:)
I hope I can make some time in the future for this

text: ThreeQ is much older than Yao, and it seems it’s never got proper wrapped as a package, so I’m not sure if it’s usable. In principal, Yao’s IR is sufficient to express QA, the problem would be how do people actually want to use QA in practice, we don’t have much use case on ourside, thus I won’t be able to design anything for that

text: A good reference would be braket’s interface for Dwave which was developed recently, it would be a nice feature to have in Yao ecosystem (if you want to work on this)
